_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE  SUMMARY 

Chelan Fruit Cooperative, (hereafter referred to as CFC) accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures, and management practices.  It is the policy of CFC to adhere to all applicable federal and state safety and environmental regulations.

CFC refrigeration personnel do respond to ammonia releases and have received training in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.120, in addition to training specifically for ammonia.  An emergency plan has been developed covering notification to public safety agencies and the public.  An evacuation plan for the plant has also been developed and all employees receive training on this plan.

At CFC anhydrous ammonia is used on-site. Ammonia is considered hazardous by EPA and is listed on the Extremely Hazardous Substance list.  Chemical properties of ammonia make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling ammonia in order to:
* Prevent unnecessary human exposure
* Reduce the threat to our personnel
* Reduce the threat to the community


Facility and Regulated Substance Handled
CFC's, Brewster Facility is a fruit processing and cold storage facility located in the city of Brewster, county of Okanogan, state of Washington.

The regulated substance used at CFC is anhydrous ammonia (CAS # 7664-41-7).
The anhydrous ammonia is used as a refrigerant. There is approximately 18,079 
pounds of anhydrous ammonia in the Brewster system. The largest vessel could potentially 
release 4,467 pounds of product.

Worst-Case and Alternative Scenarios
The off-site consequence analysis considers two ammonia release scenarios identified as worst case and alternative scenarios.  The worst case scenario is defined by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), which states that the owner or operator shall assume that the maximum quantity in the largest vessel is released.  The alternative scenario is defined as more likely to occur than the worst c

ase scenario.

Worst-Case Scenario - Failure of the largest vessel would release 4,467 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  The release would occur inside a compressor room, its walls are in direct contact with the outside.  The distance to the toxic end-point of 0.14 mg/L is 0.6 miles.  The risk radius extends past the boundaries of the plant, into public receptor areas. Distance was determined by use of RMP-COMP. 

Alternative Release Scenario - Several alternative scenarios were modeled, using ALOHA, version 5.2.1, a release from a crack, or hole, in an ammonia line under normal operating conditions, was chosen.  This alternative scenario provided the greatest toxic endpoint of 0.2 mi.  Building mitigation was used for this scenario, and it would be located inside the warehouse walls.  

All of the above scenarios are unlikely due to the safeties on the system such as temperature and pressure cutouts, computer controls and detectors, as well as pressure relief valves to prevent an overpressure situation.

A more realistic scenario would be that of a pressure relief valve lifting, discharging ammonia vapor from vents on top of the building, approximately 40 feet above the ground. 

CFC's accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:
* Initial and continued training of personnel
* Preventative maintenance programs as described in the PSM
* Use of safety equipment and procedures
* Use of accurate and effective written operating procedures

CFC complies with:
* OSHA's and Washington State's process safety management rules
* Washington State's safety regulations
* IIAR (International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration) standards for good work practices

The ammonia refrigeration system was installed to standards and local codes at the time of installation.  Piping and equipment is secured and protected; compressor (engine) room doors are generally closed, tight fitting and open outwards.  Other safety systems CFC utilizes

include:
* Computerized controls, which can be operated remotely
* Suction trap hi-level float
* High discharge pressure shut down
* Low suction pressure shut down
* High discharge temperature shut down
* Oil pressure failure shut down
* High amperes shut down
* Automatic timer to prevent short cycling via computer controls
* Oil filters plugged shut down
* 250 psi relief valves on high pressure side, to prevent overpressure situations
* 150 psi relief valves on low pressure side, to prevent overpressure situations

Operating Procedures and checklists have been prepared by CFC to be used by employees performing operational functions. Procedures are kept in the refrigeration office.  These procedures include: 
* Pre-start up procedures
* Routine operations
* Maintenance
* Response to major and minor releases
* emergency action plan

CFC has had no accidents involving ammonia in the last five years.  

Emergency Response Program
In addition to the operating procedures, CFC has established Emergency Response Guidelines for releases involving ammonia.  These procedures are part of the ongoing training.  CFC coordinates its response efforts with Okanogan Co Fire Dist #15, Okanogan Co Sheriff and Okanogan Co Emergency Management.
  
CFC ensures that each employee, who is presently operating the refrigeration process, and each employee who is newly assigned to the refrigeration process, are trained in the operating procedures that pertain to their duties.  CFC's training documentation requires that employees have the knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out the duties and responsibilities as provided in the operating procedures.

CFC also provides key employees with the 24 hours of Hazardous Materials Technician level training and the 40 hour hazardous Materials Incident Command training, in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.120(q) and WAC 296-62, Part P.  HAZWOPER refresher training is provided yearly to each employee operating the refrige

ration system to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures of the process.

CFC has prepared and implemented procedures to maintain the ongoing mechanical integrity of the refrigeration process equipment.  Some procedures or instructions were provided by refrigeration process equipment vendors.

CFC has trained each employee involved in maintaining the ongoing mechanical integrity of the refrigeration process.  To ensure that the employee can perform the job tasks in a safe manner, each employee was trained in the hazards of the process, in how to avoid or correct unsafe conditions, and in the procedures applicable to the employee's job tasks.

CFC performs inspections on the refrigeration process equipment.  Inspection procedures follow recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.  The frequency of inspections of the process equipment is consistent with the applicable manufacturers recommendations, industry standards or codes, good engineering practices, and prior operating experience.

CFC has a hot work permit program, complying with PSM of highly hazardous chemicals.  The Refrigeration Supervisor ensures that all hot work done on, or around, the covered process meets the standards of the program. CFC has identified personnel who can authorize the hot work permit, perform the hot work, and personnel who are qualified for fire watch.  These personnel are identified in the Hot Work procedures.  The permit documents that the fire prevention and protection requirements in 29 CFR 1910.252(a) have been implemented prior to beginning hot work operations.
